column1: Fond du Lac () is a city in Fond du Lac County
column2: Wisconsin
column3: United States. The population was 43
column4: 021 at the 2010 census. The city forms the core of the United States Census Bureau's Fond du Lac Metropolitan Statistical Area
column5: which includes all of Fond du Lac County (2017 population: 102
column6: 548). Fond du Lac is the 342nd largest Metropolitan Statistical Area (MSA) in the United States. The Fond du Lac MSA and the Beaver Dam (city)
column8: form the larger Fond du Lac-Beaver Dam Combined Statistical Area.

column1: Fond du Lac is French for the "bottom" or the "farthest point" of the lake
column2: so named because of its location at the bottom (south end) of Lake Winnebago.
primarily the Winnebagos but also the Potawatomi
column3: Kickapoo
column4: and Mascoutin lived or gathered in the area long before European explorers arrived. Although the identity of the first white man to explore the southern end of Lake Winnebago is uncertain
column6: followed by French fur trappers. James Doty
column7: a federal judge for the western part of the Michigan Territory
column8: thought the land at the foot of Lake Winnebago might be a good location for a city
column9: so he and his partners bought land in the area. In 1836
column11: John Arndt proposed making Fond du Lac the new capital. The motion failed
column12: and Doty convinced the legislature to choose Madison instead. Colwert
column13: Fanna Pier and Alex Tomasik were the first white residents of the area. In 1835
column14: the construction of the Military Ridge Road began. It passed through Fond du Lac
column15: connecting the forts in Wisconsin and Fort Dearborn in Illinois. The first school in Fond du Lac was built in 1843. The first railroad came to the community in 1852. About 1856
column16: the first English newspaper in Fond du Lac
column18: was founded. Logging and milling were primary industries in the late 1880s
column19: with access to the lake as the engine of the industry.

column2: the Fond du Lac County Fairgrounds was the site of an Allied prisoner of war camp that held 300 German prisoners of war guarded by 39 U.S. soldiers. The prisoners worked on peas farms and in canneries that summer.

column1: Fond du Lac has 20 listings on the National Register of Historic Places
column2: including four historic districts: the South Main Street Historic District
column3: the North Main Street Historic District
column5: and the East Division Street-Sheboygan Street Historic District. Other listings include six houses
column13: and a prehistoric site. Most of the buildings listed in the register were a result of economic prosperity following the lumber industry boom in the Fox Valley and the newly rich building residences in the area.

column5: 18.82 square miles (48.74 km2) is land and 1.29 square miles (3.34 km2) is water.Fond du Lac lies on the southern shore of Lake Winnebago. The east and west branches of the Fond du Lac River connect in the city and the river then flows into Lake Winnebago near Lakeside Park.

column1: Fond du Lac has a city manager-council form of government. The city council is composed of seven individuals
column2: who are elected to two-year terms. The current city manager is Joseph P. Moore and the council president is Brian Kolstad.Fond du Lac is represented by Dan Feyen in the 18th district of the Wisconsin Senate
column3: and by Jeremy Thiesfeldt and Michael Schraa in the 52nd and 53rd districts of the Wisconsin Assembly. At a federal level
column4: Fond du Lac falls within Wisconsin's 6th congressional district and is represented by Glenn Grothman in the United States House of Representatives.

column1: The Wisconsin Evangelical Lutheran Synod has four churches in Fond du Lac: Redeemer Lutheran Church
column2: Good Shepherd Lutheran Church
column3: St. Peter's Lutheran Church

column1: Fond du Lac's population is about one-third Roman Catholic. In 2000 the six Catholic parishes merged into a single entity called Holy Family Catholic Community. St. Louis Catholic Church burned down in 2007 and the building was demolished. The St. Patrick and St. Joseph churches closed
column2: while Sacred Heart
column3: St. Mary

column1: The mother house of the Sisters of Saint Agnes is in Fond du Lac. The order operates the city's Agnesian HealthCare and St. Agnes Hospital.Fond du Lac is the episcopal see of the Episcopal Diocese of Fond du Lac. St. Paul's Cathedral is the diocese's mother church.
Fond du Lac also has a synagogue
column2: Temple Beth Israel. Although Jewish people first came to Fond du Lac in the late 19th century
column3: the first synagogue was not established until 1914.The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints has a congregation in Fond du Lac.42.7% of Fond du Lac residents do not affiliate with any religion.

column1: Fond du Lac is served by the Fond du Lac School District. Its schools include:
Fond du Lac High School (grades 9–12)The original Fond du Lac High School
column2: built in 1922
column3: was Fond du Lac's only public high school to 2001. The name of the high school changed to L.(owell) P.(ierce?). Goodrich High School
column4: ca. 1955.  The original part of the high school
column6: was torn down about the time the new high school was built.  When the current Fond du Lac High School on Campus Dr. was built (which is still Fond du Lac's only public high school)
column7: the addition part of the former building (opened 1965)
column8: located mostly on 9th St. became partially the administration building for the school district (9th St.) and partially Riverside Elementary School (Linden St.).

column1: Private secondary schools in Fond du Lac include: Winnebago Lutheran Academy
column2: a Lutheran (Wisconsin Evangelical Lutheran Synod) high school; St. Mary Springs High School
column3: a Catholic high school; Fond du Lac Christian School
column4: an interdenominational K-12 school; and Trinity Baptist School
column5: a Baptist K-12 school.St. Mary's Springs Academy also operates an elementary school and middle school
column6: which were formerly named Fond du Lac Area Catholic Education System (FACES). Fond du Lac also has four Lutheran primary schools.Fond du Lac is the home of three colleges: Marian University
column7: a private Catholic four-year university; the University of Wisconsin-Fond du Lac
column8: a two-year campus in the University of Wisconsin Colleges; and Moraine Park Technical College
column9: a two-year technical college in the Wisconsin Technical College System.

column1: KFIZ – One of the oldest radio stations in Wisconsin
column2: broadcasts out of Fond du Lac. KFIZ first went on the air in 1922 when Oscar Huelsman turned on the transmitter. Branded as News-Talk 1450 KFIZ.

column1: WFON – Sister station to KFIZ. Country format. Branded as 107.1 The Bull.
WFDL-FM – Sunny 97.7 FM is a radio station broadcasting an Adult Contemporary format.

column1: The largest employer in Fond du Lac is Mercury Marine
column2: a division of the Brunswick Corporation. Mercury Marine
column3: which has its world headquarters in Fond du Lac
column4: is the largest maker of outboard motors in the world
column6: 500 people in its factory and offices. Other industry includes Giddings & Lewis
column8: owned by the Fives Group; Brenner Tank
column9: a builder of transport tankers; Chicago Tube & Iron
column10: a division of Olympic Steel; Saputo Cheese; and J. F. Ahern
column11: a mechanical and fire protection company.

column1: Fond du Lac is also home to a Nielsen Corporation data gathering center. Other businesses include Charter Communications
column2: Society Insurance and an office of Anthem.

column1: Fond du Lac has one hospital
column2: St. Agnes Hospital.

column1: The main retail district includes Forest Mall which includes a Kohl's and a Staples. Other retailers in Fond du Lac include Walmart
column2: Target
column3: Mills Fleet Farm and Menards.

column1: Fond du Lac is the county seat of Fond du Lac County and the site of the Fond du Lac County Fairgrounds. The Fond du Lac County Fair takes place annually in late July.
Fond du Lac is also host to Walleye Weekend
column2: an annual summer festival centered around the Mercury Marine National Walleye Fishing Tournament. Walleye Weekend
column3: usually hosted on the second weekend in June is a "Free Family Fun Festival" held in Lakeside Park on the south shore of Lake Winnebago.

column1: An annual fall festival is also held in September
column2: called Fondue Fest. The festival was first held in September 2007 when a collaboration project between The Melting Pot and Brenner Tank created and set the Guinness World Record for the world's largest fondue set. The festival has been held since.

column1: Fond du Lac has a children's museum
column2: which displays rotating child-centric exhibits.

column1: The Wisconsin Timber Rattlers and Marian University have teamed up to create the Fond du Lac Dock Spiders baseball team in 2017. The Dock Spiders are a part of the South Division of the Northwoods League. The team uses Herr-Baker Field on the Marian University campus.
The largest park in Fond du Lac
column2: Lakeside Park has more than 400 acres (1.6 km2) of open recreational space on the south end of Lake Winnebago. Year-round activities include a whitetail deer exhibit. Summer activities include flower displays
column3: boating
column5: and weddings within the park's picturesque landscape. From April 15 to October 15
column8: and its observation tower are open. Visitors can ride on a miniature train and an antique carousel. The park also has four jungle gyms and a petting zoo. A steam locomotive stands at the Main Street entrance to the park
column9: donated by the Soo Line in 1955. Lakeside Park hosts a holiday event featuring a "dancing lights" display

column1: Buttermilk Creek Park is a large
column2: grassy
column3: hilly park containing an amphitheater

column1: Other parks include: Taylor Park and Pool
column2: Butzen (Danbury) Park
column3: Jefferson Park

column1: Fond du Lac County Airport (IATA: FLD
column2: ICAO: KFLD
column3: FAA LID: FLD)Commercial airline service for Fond du Lac is provided by Appleton International Airport in Greenville and Milwaukee Mitchell International Airport in Milwaukee.

column1: Canadian National Railway operates the only railroad in Fond du Lac. Fond du Lac was the headquarters of the Wisconsin Central Railroad until 2001. It was part of the Soo Line until 1987.

Fond du Lac Area Transit is the city's local public transit operator. The first public transit in Fond du Lac was a privately owned streetcar service in the 1880s; it converted to buses from 1944 to 1967. After several private operators
column2: the bus system ceased operations in December 1967. In August 1968 the Fondy Area Bus Cooperative was established to provide bus service by support of private citizens and businesses
column3: in lieu of a municipal one; however
column4: it asked the city for financial support in 1970.

column1: The current city-owned transit system began operations on January 15
column3: following the successful passing of the referendum on November 7
column4: 1972. It operates eight bus routes (with one of those routes operating only in the morning and afternoon to service K-12 schools)
column5: as well as a Paratransit service and taxi service for areas that the bus system does not reach.
